title: PropertyGuru owners eye perfect 10
text:
There'll be few more relieved about the Australian sharemarket's expected positive start to the week than TPG, KKR and everyone else involved with Asian property play PropertyGuru.

PropertyGuru's brokers Credit Suisse and UBS are expected to launch the company's float as early as Monday, with a prospectus sent to the corporate regulator and a pricing blast email to fund managers.

It is understood PropertyGuru management will start its pitch in Hong Kong this week, before heading to the United States and then to Australia. It's something of a backward agenda compared to most Australian floats, but may help skirt around the school holidays.

PropertyGuru CEO Hari Krishnan is expected in Hong Kong and the US this week, to pitch his company's mooted Australian float to offshore investors. Brook Mitchell

PropertyGuru looks like the type of float that would be best served by a buoyant market. It's a high-growth story and will come to market with a high multiple to match.

It is understood funds were asked to think about up to 10-times revenue, which would fit pretty neatly with the valuation Credit Suisse analysts put on the stock this time last week. Such a deal would imply a $S1.05 billion ($1.12 billion) company on a market capitalisation basis.

But 10-times is pretty unprecedented when it comes to floats on the ASX. Tearway WiseTech Global got the ball rolling with a deal at about 6.5-times one-year forward revenue back in 2016, while more recently we have seen FINEOS Corporation at 5.6-times forward revenue and Prospa at 3.3-times.

Credit Suisse and UBS are expected to kick off this week's pitch with news about demands into the deal so far, which is becoming a trend in IPO bookbuilds.
description: There'll be few more relieved about the Australian sharemarket's expected positive start to the week than KKR and everyone involved with Asian property play PropertyGuru.
